persona.name: Eloise Gardner

occupation.title: Junior Front-end Developer / Part-time Web Developer
occupation.organization: Small Cleveland-based digital agency (contract, ~25 hours/week) and occasional freelance projects
occupation.description: Eloise works as a junior front-end developer for a small digital agency that serves local businesses, non-profits, and arts organizations. Her primary responsibilities are building responsive interfaces in React, implementing accessible HTML/CSS patterns, debugging cross-browser issues, performing light UX research for client work, writing and maintaining component documentation, and deploying static sites via the agency's workflow (Netlify/deploy scripts). She also handles small freelance projects (portfolio microsites, event landing pages) on weekends. Typical day tasks: turn designs into components, troubleshoot layout issues, write semantic markup and ARIA labels, collaborate with a designer on micro-interactions, and communicate status to the project manager. Skills centrally used at work include: JavaScript (ES6+), React, CSS-in-JS and SASS, Git/GitHub, basic Node tooling, Chrome DevTools, accessibility testing tools (axe, Lighthouse), and basic SQL for small CMS data queries. She is learning TypeScript and serverless basics in her spare time. Eloise frequently tutors first-year students part-time through the university's tutoring program and volunteers at weekend coding meetups for teens.

persona.education: Bachelor of Science in Information Science, Cleveland State University (expected May 2025). Coursework emphasis on human-computer interaction, front-end development, databases, and accessible design. GPA 3.4. Member of the student game-dev club and campus women-in-tech group. Completed a 10-week summer internship at a small Cleveland digital agency building client microsites and accessibility audits. Regular library user and subscriber to an academic digital journal service and two coding-learning platforms (one paid).
long_term_goals: Become a senior front-end engineer (3–5 years), then transition to a product engineering role focusing on accessibility and UX.
Ship an indie narrative game within five years as a side project and publish it on itch.io and later on Steam.
Reach financial stability: pay off student loans within 7–10 years, build an emergency fund (6 months of expenses), and eventually purchase a small starter home in the region.
Develop a teaching presence: run workshops for teens (especially girls) to teach basic programming and confidence with technology.
Travel to at least 15 countries, focusing on Japan, Portugal, and Iceland, combining sightseeing with research into local game and design scenes.
Be known for creating interfaces and experiences that are truly accessible for people with disabilities.
Maintain strong social ties and a creative side hustle that keeps life varied — balancing a stable technical career with creative expression.
Establish a side-business for freelance front-end and UI work that produces a modest supplemental income.
Continue formal learning: earn relevant certifications (accessibility, React) and consider a part-time master's if it aligns with career goals.
Be emotionally resilient and financially independent enough to support family needs if required.

style.verbal: Conversational, quick-paced, friendly; mixes casual internet idioms and tech vocabulary. Uses phrases like 'ship it', 'LGTM', 'that's a UX smell', 'low-fi prototype', and occasionally gamer slang. Tends to pepper speech with short laughter (a soft 'haha') and emojis in written messages. Speaks with a mild, generalized Midwestern American accent — not strongly regional but occasional vowel flattening on words like 'park' and 'caught'.
style.written: Prefers asynchronous communication (Slack, DMs, email) for work; writes concise updates with code snippets and gifs for tone. Uses bullet lists for tasks and headings when documenting. In social DMs uses more emojis, GIFs, and exclamation points. Grammar is good; she values clarity but favors friendliness over formality.
style.nonverbal: Fidgets with a ring or the edge of her phone case when thinking; tilts head slightly when listening; smiles easily and uses open gestures. When concentrating she bites her lower lip briefly and will push her hair behind her ear. Enthusiastic hand motions when excited about ideas.
style.dress: Everyday mix of secondhand thrifted pieces and comfortable basics: oversize sweaters, high-waisted jeans, dad sneakers or platform sandals, often a capsule of muted colors mixed with one bright accessory (vivid scarf or enamel pin). At work she opts for 'smart casual' — simple blouse or band T-shirt under an open cardigan, neat sneakers. Owns one blazer for interviews or presentations.
style.mannerisms & etiquette: Polite but direct. Prefers collaboration and code reviews that are constructive; will call out unclear requirements and ask clarifying questions. Likes to be thanked publicly in team channels. Not overly formal with elders but defers politely in hierarchical contexts.
style.communication preferences: Prefers Slack for quick questions, email for formal items, Notion or Google Docs for collaborative documents, and short recorded Loom videos when demonstrating UI issues. Avoids long voice calls unless necessary; when on calls she shares an agenda and loves using a virtual whiteboard.

traits: Highly curious and intellectually hungry — frequently chasing new frameworks, design patterns, and narrative techniques for games.
Open-minded: enjoys novelty and is receptive to different cultures and perspectives.
Socially outgoing: enjoys meetup groups, game nights, and co-working days; easily starts conversations with strangers about creative projects.
Energetic and enthusiastic in groups; often volunteers to organize social events or hack weekend teams.
Detail-oriented about code and design, sometimes pernickety about accessibility details.
Some impatience with process slowdown; prefers iterative speed over overplanning.
Emotionally empathetic: notices when peers are stressed and offers help or an ear.
Competitive in games and friendly challenges, but keeps games light-hearted and joking.
Anxious about money and future stability — financial stress is a recurring worry.
Creative and playful: collects small ritual objects (stickers, enamel pins) and sketches character ideas in notebooks.

openness.comment: Very high — loves new ideas, travel, creative projects, reading broadly, and experimenting with side projects.

conscientiousness.comment: Above average — organized around work and study, uses task lists and planners, but sometimes procrastinates on unpleasant admin (taxes, loan paperwork).

extraversion.comment: High — energized by social events, leads study groups, enjoys networking meetups, though she still values quiet solo time for coding sprints.

agreeableness.comment: Moderately high — cooperative and helpful, but can hold firm on technical or ethical stances (e.g., accessibility).

neuroticism.comment: Mildly elevated — has worries about finances and career trajectory, experiences occasional stress-related sleeplessness and performance anxiety before presentations.

interests: Indie and AAA video games (particularly narrative-driven and puzzle titles).
Fiction (contemporary literary fiction and speculative fiction) and long-form journalism.
Human-computer interaction and accessible design patterns.
UI/UX micro-interactions and motion design.
Pixel art and character concept sketching.
Podcasts about tech culture, design, and personal finance.
Board games and monthly boardgame nights with friends.
Small gallery shows and local music venues.
Streaming TV: serialized dramas, sci-fi, and character-driven comedies.
Short game jams (48–72 hour creative sprints).
Coffee shop work sessions and co-working meetups.
Reading newsletters on inflation, economic policy, and housing markets.
Sustainable fashion and secondhand shopping.
Photography: candid street and event photography.
Travel planning and researching local cafes and indie game studios.
Cooking new vegetarian recipes and baking occasional desserts.
Fitness classes that are social (dance, climbing) rather than gym machines.
Creative writing prompts and short fiction experimentation.
Watching speedruns and esports casually for technique and spectacle.
DIY electronics and cheap microcontroller projects (basic Arduino/ESP32).
likes: Favorite video games: Untitled Goose Game (for humor), Celeste (for narrative and challenge), Stardew Valley (for relaxation during stressful weeks), Hades (for replayable mechanics), and recent indie narrative releases.
Platform preferences: PC for indie games and experimental tools; Nintendo Switch for portability and local co-op; mobile for quick puzzle games on commutes.
Book favorites/authors: Ottessa Moshfegh, Kazuo Ishiguro, Ann Patchett, long feature pieces from The Atlantic and The New Yorker.
Music: lo-fi study playlists, synthwave for focused coding, indie pop for commuting, small local bands for nights out.
Podcasts: design critiques, The Vergecast, Reply All back catalog, How I Built This episodes related to tech founders she admires.
Coffee: oat milk lattes or americano; likes small neighborhood cafés more than large chains; appreciates a quiet corner table and reliable Wi-Fi for work sessions.
Cafés she prefers: an independent café within walking distance that roasts their own beans, a student-friendly library cafe, and a small boardgame-café downtown.
Ambience preferences in cafés: soft indie music, plants, natural light, outlets near seating, tolerant staff for someone working for hours.
Snacks and food: kimchi fried rice, shakshuka on lazy weekends, good bakery sourdough, and a preference for spicy pickles.
Streaming services: Netflix for shows, Crunchyroll for anime, and itch.io for discovering indie games.
Social life: weekly boardgame night, monthly meetup for women-in-tech, occasional open-mic nights for friends.
Tools: VSCode with a curated set of extensions, Figma for UI work, Notion for organization, and Obsidian for personal notes and sketches.
Gadgets: mid-range smartphone (keeps it for 2–3 years), a refurbished MacBook Air for school and light dev work, and a mechanical keyboard bought through a group buy.
Fashion: likes thrifted band tees, a reliable denim jacket, and an old pair of Converse for everyday use.
Aesthetics: soft neon accents, warm neutrals, houseplants (pothos and snake plant), stickers on her laptop.
Gaming social habits: plays co-op games with two close friends weekly and participates in Discord communities for favorite indie studios.
Learning habits: prefers short, project-based tutorials and hackathons over long formal lectures.
Dislikes about modern tech: poor accessibility, dark patterns in UX, surprise fees in apps, and opaque privacy policies.
Leisure reading: long threads on Twitter/X and curated newsletters; also follows a few Substack writers on tech and culture.
Media consumption habits: switches between platforms; heavy short-form social media in evenings (Instagram/TikTok) and long-form in mornings (podcasts/articles).
dislikes: Poorly designed interfaces that block access for people with disabilities.
Paywalls that restrict important civic journalism (but will pay for a few trusted outlets).
Overly corporate, hollow-sounding mission statements from companies she considers working for.
Long, micromanaging meetings that could be an async note.
Inflation and rising grocery/housing costs — views it as a very big, personal problem.
Unclear pricing on subscription services and sneaky auto-renewals.
Mandatory social events at work that feel performative.
Toxic gamer cultures (harassment in online communities).
When people don't respond to agreed-upon deadlines or ghost collaborators.
Cold, barren office spaces with no personality.
Low-quality, mass-produced fast fashion — prefers durable thrifted items.
Aggressive or predatory lending practices and debt traps.
Being pigeonholed into a single role; dislikes narrow job definitions.
People who dismiss accessibility as unnecessary.
Stale coffee in the office.
Excessive advertising/popups interrupting reading or playing.
Overly glossy influencer culture that promotes unrealistic spending.
Public transit cuts in her city, which make commuting harder.
Being spoken down to because of her age.
Stereotyping women in tech as less committed or less technical.

beliefs: Inflation is a very big problem and directly affects household affordability; price increases shape many life decisions (rent, food, travel).
Access to affordable higher education is crucial; student loans are a major burden that should be addressed through policy reform.
Technology should be designed for people first — accessibility is non-negotiable.
Small businesses and local arts organizations give cities character and should receive support.
Remote and hybrid work options improve quality of life and widen hiring pools; people should be judged on outcomes, not presenteeism.
Mental health resources should be normalized and made easily available (counseling on campus, employer mental health days).
Internet privacy matters: companies should be transparent about data use and give users real control.
Public transit investment is worthwhile, especially for younger workers who can’t afford cars.
Students and early-career workers need clearer pathways to mentorship and apprenticeships.
Creative work and technical work can coexist; a stable technical career should not preclude creative side projects.
Meritocracy is imperfect — background, networks, and chance shape outcomes; active measures are needed to open doors.
Unionization or collective bargaining can be an appropriate tool for workers in tech and creative fields.
Climate change is real and pressing; individual choices matter but systemic action is required.
Diversity in tech leads to better products and should be pursued sincerely rather than performatively.
Local journalism is essential for civic health and should be funded in sustainable ways.
Voting matters, especially on local and school-board elections that shape daily life.
Arts funding at the municipal level is worth defending; it feeds community vibrancy and careers.
Affordable childcare and paid family leave strengthen workforce participation for young adults.
Financial literacy education in high school would have helped her and should be expanded.
Healthcare ought to be accessible and not bankrupt people for routine issues.
Student debt forgiveness targeted to low-income borrowers is compassionate and practical.
Big tech needs stronger regulatory guardrails to prevent monopolistic behavior and protect users.
Designers and engineers have a responsibility to avoid dark patterns that manipulate users.
Mentorship is powerful; she owes much to early mentors and believes in paying it forward.
Gig work should provide more stability and protections for workers who depend on it.
Housing policy needs innovative solutions — zoning, more diverse housing types, and tenant protections.
Creative communities flourish when there are accessible, affordable spaces for rehearsal and collaboration.
Voting with your wallet has limits — coordinated policy action is necessary to address systemic problems.
Being politically engaged at local levels yields concrete benefits (transit routes preserved, grants for arts, rent ordinances).
People deserve privacy but also benefits from responsibly-used data (e.g., accessible transit apps) when consented to.
Civic tech that supports community decision-making is an area she values and would like to contribute to.
Learning how to build things (code, craft, music) is empowering — schools should support practical creative education.
She is skeptical of quick-fix entrepreneurial rhetoric that dismisses structural barriers as mere mindset issues.
Work should have fair compensation and clarity about expectations — unpaid internships are often exploitative.
Personal growth is lifelong: changing majors, switching careers, or pivoting at 25 is completely normal and acceptable.
skills: Proficient in HTML5, CSS3 (including responsive design and flex/grid systems).
Practical experience with JavaScript (ES6+) and React for building component-driven UIs.
Familiar with TypeScript basics and actively practicing migrating small projects.
Experience with version control: Git workflows, GitHub PRs, branching, and resolving merge conflicts.
Accessibility (a11y) auditing skills: semantic markup, ARIA basics, keyboard navigation testing, and screen-reader checks.
Design tools: comfortable in Figma for translating mockups into developer specs, creating simple prototypes.
Basic backend knowledge: REST APIs, simple serverless functions, and SQL queries for content-driven sites.
Debugging skills using Chrome DevTools and browser-based performance profiling.
Testing: writes unit-level tests for components and basic end-to-end smoke tests (Cypress exposure).
Soft skills: clear written communication, client-facing meeting etiquette, ability to break down technical concepts for nontechnical stakeholders.
Time management: uses task boards and pomodoro techniques for focused work sprints.
Teaching/tutoring: explains programming fundamentals to first-year students and high-school workshop attendees.
Project maintenance: capable of documenting components, maintaining a small style system, and handling deployments.
Creative practice: pixel art, basic animation frames, and narrative game design principles.
Budgeting fundamentals: tracks expenses, prioritizes debts, and manages a modest side-gig ledger.
Public speaking: comfortable presenting demo builds and giving short lightning talks at meetups.
Photography basics: composition, natural-light portraiture, and basic Lightroom edits.
Basic home DIY and sewing repairs for clothing; reluctant but competent at small tasks.
Customer empathy and client negotiation at a junior level.
Multitasking across school, part-time job, and side projects while maintaining deliverables.

general: Checks phone first thing in the morning and again before bed — uses it for news, messages, and quick game levels.
Maintains a shared Google Sheet budget and updates it weekly after grocery runs.
Carries a small sketchbook for game ideas and character doodles; often annotates UI ideas in margins.
Favors asynchronous work communication and leaves concise summaries after meetings.
When stressed she double-checks emails and rewrites messages before sending.
Uses playlists to create focus states: instrumental for deep work, upbeat for chores, lo-fi for casual reading.
Saves articles to a Read-It-Later app; reviews saved items during weekend transit or slow times.
Plays a 90–120-minute gaming session most evenings as a way to decompress; longer sessions on weekends.
Prefers splitting grocery runs into smaller, frequent purchases to manage cash flow.
Attends one meetup or community event per week on average (design nights, game jams, tech talks).

morning: Wakes between 7:30–8:30 AM on weekdays (later on weekends).
Checks calendar and messages, then brews a coffee or picks up a latte at a nearby cafe.
Does a 20–30 minute focused work block or reviews code before heading to campus or the office.
Skims headlines and a favorite newsletter while eating toast or yogurt.
Picks a small task from the to-do list and completes it before lunch to build momentum.
workday: Splits the day into 90-minute focused coding blocks with short breaks.
Starts with a standup or daily recap in Slack; updates a task board with clear acceptance criteria.
Pushes incremental PRs and writes concise PR descriptions; pairs with a senior dev on tougher tickets.
Eats lunch either at the student union, a local cafe, or brings leftovers to save money.
Uses late afternoons for meetings, learning (course modules), or client communications when cognitive energy dips.
Closes work tasks with a short summary message and a plan for next steps.
evening: Joins friends for boardgame night or co-working café sessions a few nights per week.
Spends 60–120 minutes on a side project — coding, pixel art, or narrative writing.
Cooks a simple meal (stir-fry, pasta) or orders in when budgets allow.
Winds down with streaming content or light reading; avoids heavy social media right before bed most nights.
Tracks sleep with a phone app occasionally and adjusts bedtime to aim for 7–8 hours.
weekend: Longer creative sessions (game jam participation or portfolio updates) and in-person meetups.
Errands: grocery shopping, laundromat, thrift-store browsing, and occasional volunteering at a youth coding workshop.
One long social outing: visiting a gallery, concert, or day-trip to a nearby town.
Reflects and plans the coming week in a Sunday evening ritual: updating Notion and arranging tasks.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active. Nearsighted (requires glasses for distance; uses contact lenses occasionally). No chronic illnesses. Tends toward seasonal allergies (hay fever) and occasional tension headaches after long screen sessions. Mild exercise routine: climbing gym twice a week and a weekly dance class. Sleep is variable during heavy school deadlines. No history of major surgeries.
health.mental: Occasional anxiety tied to financial uncertainty and deadlines; practices breathing exercises and uses a therapy app (and sees a campus counselor when needed). Has a family history of mood disorders (maternal line) which she is aware of and monitors. Uses journaling and creative outlets to manage stress. No diagnosed severe mental illness currently, but recognizes moments of low mood and seeks support proactively.
health.substance_use: Drinks socially (1–3 drinks on nights out), rarely smokes, does not use illicit drugs regularly. Avoids daily caffeine excess but enjoys occasional specialty coffee.
health.medical_care: Up-to-date on routine vaccines, uses campus health services for minor issues, has a primary-care physician for annual checkups, uses over-the-counter meds for colds and headaches.
health.reproductive_health: On birth control (oral contraceptive) for period regulation and contraception; regular gynecological checkups.

relationships.details: Close relationship with her mother (mid-40s, elementary school teacher) and father (late 40s, small business owner). One older half-brother (24) lives in another state; relationship is warm but not close. Parents are supportive but sometimes anxious about financial planning and career stability. Family background is White, Non-Hispanic, with multigenerational Midwestern roots. Family gatherings are low-key and involve shared dinners and board games.

Single and casually dating. Uses dating apps sporadically; prefers meeting through mutual friends or local events. Values emotional intelligence and shared creative interests in partners. Has had two semi-serious relationships in college; last relationship ended amicably 8 months ago.

Broad social network: a core group of 6 close friends (college peers, game-dev collaborators), plus many acquaintances from meetups and part-time jobs. Hosts monthly game nights and a quarterly 'skill-share' where friends present short mini-workshops (one friend taught basic guitar last month). Is the connector who introduces people from different social circles.
relationships.closeness: Close friends serve as emotional support and collaborators on side projects. Calls one friend weekly to check in and vent.

relationships.details: Mentor relationship with a former internship supervisor who provides career advice. Maintains contacts with a couple of senior engineers from LinkedIn and the local meetup scene. Tutors underclassmen at the university and receives mentoring requests from new coders occasionally.
Active volunteer at youth coding workshops and local game-jam community. Participates in campus women-in-tech events and occasional civic tech volunteer projects for the city.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized Midwestern suburb; family emphasized thrift, practicality, and community involvement.
First learned basic HTML in high school from a gifted teacher who let the class build a class website — this sparked her interest in development.
Paid her own way through college partially with a part-time job at a campus coffee shop and freelance website work for local bands and artists.

Internship highlight: fixed a persistent accessibility bug for a non-profit site that improved screen-reader navigation — the client sent a thank-you note that made her realize the social impact of her work.
Has a small but curated laptop sticker collection that signals communities she values (women-in-tech, local game studios, accessibility-minded orgs).
Her favorite childhood memory is road-tripping to the lakeshore with cousins and pitching a tent, then sketching UI ideas on the picnic table.
Was on her university's Dean's List one semester after recovering from a heavy midterm season and reorganizing her study methods.
An early mistake: a finance app subscription auto-renewed and she missed the charge; since then she tracks auto-renewal dates and uses calendar reminders.
Has a 10-page, half-illustrated game concept document begun in 2022 that she revisits and expands a little every month.
Volunteered during a local election doing phone banking and was surprised at how practical and immediate local politics feel.

Anecdote: once accidentally deployed a debug branch to a client's staging site because of a typo in the CI config — learned CI naming discipline the hard way and now has a personal pre-deploy checklist.
Won a small prize at a campus hackathon for a team-built accessibility toolbar extension.
Saved up for and took a solo 10-day trip to Portland, OR after her first year of college; that trip cemented her love of solo travel and small cafes.
Has a faint tattoo of a tiny pixel heart on her wrist that she got during a celebratory weekend after graduating high school.
Her oldest friend is someone she met in middle school and they've kept up through moves and life changes.
Prefers to keep politics conversational and focused on practical outcomes when among mixed groups, but will advocate strongly for accessible design and local arts funding.
Has a mild fear of public speaking but has improved through giving several short talks at meetups.
Once organized a late-night community game-testing session that drew 40 people to a cramped campus room and became a recurring event.
Keeps a small emergency fund (a few hundred dollars) in a separate savings account for unexpected expenses like phone repairs or urgent travel.
Owns an old bike used for short commutes and urban errands; repairs punctures herself with a YouTube tutorial.
Is ambivalent about moving to a larger tech hub — attracted by opportunities but fearful of rent and living costs pushed by inflation.
Loves her university's library and frequently borrows physical books even when she reads some content digitally.
Has a mild sweet tooth; bakes brownies for friends during exam weeks as a stress ritual.
Has done pro-bono UX reviews for a local community center's website to help them qualify for a small grant.
Learnt basic Spanish in high school and uses translation apps when traveling; wants to be more conversational for future travel.
Kept a pandemic sketch-diary during COVID-19 lockdowns which she occasionally flips through for creative inspiration.
Volunteered as a crisis-text-line operator for a short term, which deepened her empathy and awareness of mental health support resources.
Believes in small daily rituals: a 5-minute morning stretch, a clean desk on Monday, and a Sunday planning ritual with candles and music.
Once burned dinner while debugging a production issue — now she keeps frozen meals as a fail-safe during hard deadlines.
Collects receipts and ticket stubs in a small box as mementos of low-cost adventures and gigs.
Has a tendency to over-commit to meetups because she hates missing community events; learning to say no more often.
Is an early adopter of small productivity experiments (e.g., inbox-zero, two-minute rule) and iterates what works.
Dream scenario: finding a long-term job within commuting distance that allows flexible hours and a small, stable income to support creative projects.
Keeps an annual 'growth list' in her notes with 10 personal and technical goals she revisits and checks progress against every quarter.
